trans-unit.source: Service Bus AMQP overview | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Service Bus AMQP overview | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn about using the Advanced Message Queuing Protocol (AMQP) 1.0 in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn about using the Advanced Message Queuing Protocol (AMQP) 1.0 in Azure.

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 support in Service Bus
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 support in Service Bus

trans-unit.source: Both the Azure Service Bus cloud service and on-prem <link><linkText>Service Bus for Windows Server (Service Bus 1.1)</linkText><title></title></link> support the Advanced Message Queueing Protocol (AMQP) 1.0.
trans-unit.target: Both the Azure Service Bus cloud service and on-prem <link><linkText>Service Bus for Windows Server (Service Bus 1.1)</linkText><title></title></link> support the Advanced Message Queueing Protocol (AMQP) 1.0.

trans-unit.source: AMQP enables you to build cross-platform, hybrid applications using an open standard protocol.
trans-unit.target: AMQP enables you to build cross-platform, hybrid applications using an open standard protocol.

trans-unit.source: You can construct applications using components that are built using different languages and frameworks, and that run on different operating systems.
trans-unit.target: You can construct applications using components that are built using different languages and frameworks, and that run on different operating systems.

trans-unit.source: All these components can connect to Service Bus and seamlessly exchange structured business messages efficiently and at full fidelity.
trans-unit.target: All these components can connect to Service Bus and seamlessly exchange structured business messages efficiently and at full fidelity.

trans-unit.source: Introduction: What is AMQP 1.0 and why is it important?
trans-unit.target: Introduction: What is AMQP 1.0 and why is it important?

trans-unit.source: Traditionally, message-oriented middleware products have used proprietary protocols for communication between client applications and brokers.
trans-unit.target: Traditionally, message-oriented middleware products have used proprietary protocols for communication between client applications and brokers.

trans-unit.source: This means that once you've selected a particular vendor's messaging broker, you must use that vendor's libraries to connect your client applications to that broker.
trans-unit.target: This means that once you've selected a particular vendor's messaging broker, you must use that vendor's libraries to connect your client applications to that broker.

trans-unit.source: This results in a degree of dependence on that vendor, since porting an application to a different product requires code changes in all the connected applications.
trans-unit.target: This results in a degree of dependence on that vendor, since porting an application to a different product requires code changes in all the connected applications.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, connecting messaging brokers from different vendors is tricky.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, connecting messaging brokers from different vendors is tricky.

trans-unit.source: This typically requires application-level bridging to move messages from one system to another and to translate between their proprietary message formats.
trans-unit.target: This typically requires application-level bridging to move messages from one system to another and to translate between their proprietary message formats.

trans-unit.source: This is a common requirement; for example, when you must provide a new unified interface to older disparate systems, or integrate IT systems following a merger.
trans-unit.target: This is a common requirement; for example, when you must provide a new unified interface to older disparate systems, or integrate IT systems following a merger.

trans-unit.source: The software industry is a fast-moving business; new programming languages and application frameworks are introduced at a sometimes bewildering pace.
trans-unit.target: The software industry is a fast-moving business; new programming languages and application frameworks are introduced at a sometimes bewildering pace.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the requirements of IT systems evolve over time and developers want to take advantage of the latest platform features.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the requirements of IT systems evolve over time and developers want to take advantage of the latest platform features.

trans-unit.source: However, sometimes the selected messaging vendor does not support these platforms.
trans-unit.target: However, sometimes the selected messaging vendor does not support these platforms.

trans-unit.source: Because messaging protocols are proprietary, it's not possible for others to provide libraries for these new platforms.
trans-unit.target: Because messaging protocols are proprietary, it's not possible for others to provide libraries for these new platforms.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, you must use approaches such as building gateways or bridges that enable you to continue to use the messaging product.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, you must use approaches such as building gateways or bridges that enable you to continue to use the messaging product.

trans-unit.source: The development of the Advanced Message Queuing Protocol (AMQP) 1.0 was motivated by these issues.
trans-unit.target: The development of the Advanced Message Queuing Protocol (AMQP) 1.0 was motivated by these issues.

trans-unit.source: It originated at JP Morgan Chase, who, like most financial services firms, are heavy users of message-oriented middleware.
trans-unit.target: It originated at JP Morgan Chase, who, like most financial services firms, are heavy users of message-oriented middleware.

trans-unit.source: The goal was simple: to create an open-standard messaging protocol that made it possible to build message-based applications using components built using different languages, frameworks, and operating systems, all using best-of-breed components from a range of suppliers.
trans-unit.target: The goal was simple: to create an open-standard messaging protocol that made it possible to build message-based applications using components built using different languages, frameworks, and operating systems, all using best-of-breed components from a range of suppliers.

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 technical features
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 technical features

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 is an efficient, reliable, wire-level messaging protocol that you can use to build robust, cross-platform, messaging applications.
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 is an efficient, reliable, wire-level messaging protocol that you can use to build robust, cross-platform, messaging applications.

trans-unit.source: The protocol has a simple goal: to define the mechanics of the secure, reliable, and efficient transfer of messages between two parties.
trans-unit.target: The protocol has a simple goal: to define the mechanics of the secure, reliable, and efficient transfer of messages between two parties.

trans-unit.source: The messages themselves are encoded using a portable data representation that enables heterogeneous senders and receivers to exchange structured business messages at full fidelity.
trans-unit.target: The messages themselves are encoded using a portable data representation that enables heterogeneous senders and receivers to exchange structured business messages at full fidelity.

trans-unit.source: The following is a summary of the most important features:
trans-unit.target: The following is a summary of the most important features:

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 is a Standard (with a capital 'S')
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 is a Standard (with a capital 'S')

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 has been in development since 2008 by a core group of more than 20 companies, both technology suppliers and end-user firms.
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 has been in development since 2008 by a core group of more than 20 companies, both technology suppliers and end-user firms.

trans-unit.source: During that time, user firms have contributed their real-world business requirements and the technology vendors have evolved the protocol to meet those requirements.
trans-unit.target: During that time, user firms have contributed their real-world business requirements and the technology vendors have evolved the protocol to meet those requirements.

trans-unit.source: Throughout the process, vendors have participated in workshops in which they collaborated to validate the interoperability between their implementations.
trans-unit.target: Throughout the process, vendors have participated in workshops in which they collaborated to validate the interoperability between their implementations.

trans-unit.source: In October 2011, the development work transitioned to a technical committee within the Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards (OASIS) and the OASIS AMQP 1.0 Standard was released in October 2012.
trans-unit.target: In October 2011, the development work transitioned to a technical committee within the Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards (OASIS) and the OASIS AMQP 1.0 Standard was released in October 2012.

trans-unit.source: The following firms participated in the technical committee during the development of the standard:
trans-unit.target: The following firms participated in the technical committee during the development of the standard:

trans-unit.source: Some of the commonly cited benefits of open standards include:
trans-unit.target: Some of the commonly cited benefits of open standards include:

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 and Service Bus
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 and Service Bus

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 support in Azure Service Bus means that you can now leverage the Service Bus queuing and publish/subscribe brokered messaging features from a range of platforms using an efficient binary protocol.
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 support in Azure Service Bus means that you can now leverage the Service Bus queuing and publish/subscribe brokered messaging features from a range of platforms using an efficient binary protocol.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, you can build applications comprised of components built using a mix of languages, frameworks, and operating systems.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, you can build applications comprised of components built using a mix of languages, frameworks, and operating systems.

trans-unit.source: The following figure illustrates an example deployment in which Java clients running on Linux, written using the standard Java Message Service (JMS) API and .NET clients running on Windows, exchange messages via Service Bus using AMQP 1.0.
trans-unit.target: The following figure illustrates an example deployment in which Java clients running on Linux, written using the standard Java Message Service (JMS) API and .NET clients running on Windows, exchange messages via Service Bus using AMQP 1.0.

trans-unit.source: Figure 1: Example deployment scenario showing cross-platform messaging using Service Bus and AMQP 1.0
trans-unit.target: Figure 1: Example deployment scenario showing cross-platform messaging using Service Bus and AMQP 1.0
